text: warning a fiddy ofoh bees should not
watch this video the attack of a boa
constrictor can be heart-stopping if
you're watching it but what about for
the rat the conventional wisdom has been
that constrictors like Boas kill prey
with suffocation that idea has been
questioned but not tested until now
researchers at Dickinson College
outfitted rats under anesthesia with
blood pressure monitors and heart
sensors then they offered them to both
they found that cutting off circulation
was what killed the rat not suffocation
if the rat had been awake it would have
lost consciousness quickly within 6
seconds of the strike the rats blood
pressure dropped by half also blood
potassium levels shot up to dangerous
levels and heart rhythms went haywire
any one of these effects could be deadly
which shows how efficient constriction
is for a predator and that may be why it
evolved very early in the snake family
tree
you
